channel.title: Quadratic Bézier Curve Formula
channel.description:
I don't understand two portions of the following formula.
[img]http://upload.wikimedia.org/math/2/d/5/2d5e5d58562d8ec2c35f16df98d2b974.png[/img]
How do I solve, or what do I do, with the [i]'P'[/i] variables?
What does the [i]'B'[/i] signify? How do I treat the equation when this symbol is used?

item.title: Quadratic Bézier Curve Formula
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

because you know that T є [0,1] this means t is the variable so the value of P you would take to be constant so maybe its the co-ordinate corresponding to your other axis

Read full topic

item.title: Quadratic Bézier Curve Formula
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

I knew that part.

I’m asking how do I fill-it-in since it’s neither an x-coordinate nor a y-coordinate, but a ‘P’ value which I don’t known what to do with…

For example, what’s the result of the following operation:

new Point(30, 30) + 30

Nothing because it can’t be done. Same thing goes with the equation? How do you fill in the ‘P’ values so that they are usable with the equation?

yeah, my explanations suck…

Read full topic

item.title: Quadratic Bézier Curve Formula
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

I would see this as B is a function of t similar to how you get f(x) where f is the function of x. So that indicates your line. The P has multiple values thats why they are labelled like they are, so if it were points in a line the 0,1 and 2 denote which point you are talking about
EDIT: just looked at it on wikipedia it even tells you

A quadratic Bézier curve is the path traced by the function B(t), given points P0, P1, and P2,

Read full topic
